column.name: SECRETARIAT
column.value: Secretariat to the Convention on Biological Diversity (in Montreal, Canada)

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The objective of the CBD is to conserve biological diversity, promote the sustainable use of its components, and encourage equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of the utilisation of genetic resources. Such equitable sharing includes appropriate access to genetic resources, as well as appropriate transfer of technology, taking into account existing rights over such resources and such tecnology.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: The CBD was developed during the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 1992).

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety to the Convention on Biological Diversity

column.name: SECRETARIAT
column.value: Secretariat to the Convention on Biological Diversity (in Montreal, Canada)

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The Protocol aims at ensuring an adequate level of protection in the field of the safe transfer, handling and use of living modified organisms (LMOs) resulting from modern biotechnology. It establishes a harmonised set of international rules and procedures designed to ensure that countries are provided with the relevant information to enable them to make informed decisions before agreeing to the import of LMOs. It also ensures that LMO shipments are accompanied by appropriate identification documentation.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: The Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety to the Convention on Biological Diversity was adopted by the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on 29 January 2000.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Council Directive 91/692/EEC of 23 December 1991 standardizing and rationalizing reports on the implementation of certain Directives relating to the environment as amended by Regulation 1882/2003/EC

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: Articles 2 - 5 of the directive set out the frequency and nature of reports to be made by MS for legislation specified in the annexes of the Standardised Reporting Directive.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: The 1985 Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: Under the auspices of the United Nations Environment Programme, the Governments of the world endorsed The Vienna Convention on the Protection of the Ozone Layer in 1985. Through this Convention, Governments committed themselves to protect the ozone layer and to co-operate with each other in scientific research to improve understanding of the atmospheric processes.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: Council Decision 88/540/EEC of 14 October 1988 concerning the conclusion of the Vienna Convention for the protection of the ozone layer and the Montreal Protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer is available at: http://eur-lex.europa.eu/smartapi/cgi/sga_doc?smartapi!celexapi!prod!CELEXnumdoc&lg=en&numdoc=388D0540

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2000/76/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 4 December 2000 on the incineration of waste

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The aim of this Directive is to prevent or to limit as far as practicable negative effects on the environment, in particular pollution by emissions into air, soil, surface water and groundwater, and the resulting risks to human health, from the incineration and co-incineration of waste. This aim shall be met by means of stringent operational conditions and technical requirements and emission limit values for waste incineration and co-incineration plants.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Convention on the International Commission for the Protection of the Elbe

column.name: LEGAL_NAME
column.value: Convention on the international Commission for the protection of the Elbe

column.name: SECRETARIAT
column.value: International Commission for the Protection of the Elbe

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The contracting parties shall cooperate in the International Commission for the Protection of the Elbe to prevent the pollution of the Elbe and its drainage area. The main goals are the possibility to produce drinking water from water pumped from the river acompanying groundwater, possibility to use the water and sediments for agriculture, return to a close to natural ecosystem with a healthy species diversity, and reducing the bad effects of Elbe river basin on the North Sea.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Convention for the protection of the Rhine

column.name: SECRETARIAT
column.value: International Commission for the Protection of the Rhine (ICPR)

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: Art. 2) This convention applies to: a) the Rhine b) ground water interacting with the Rhine; c)aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems which interact or could again interact with the Rhine d) the Rhine catchment area, insofar as its pollution by noxious substances adversely affect the Rhine e) the Rhine catchment area, insofar as it is of importance for flood prevention and protection along the Rhine.

column.name: SECRETARIAT
column.value: UNECE Environment, Housing and Land Management Division

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: 36 countries have ratified the Water Convention (see status of ratification on Convention website for a list). It enters into force in a new member 90 days after signature. Under the Convention no reporting is required but Parties at their meetings share information on their implementation of the Convention and of soft law instruments (recommendations, guidelines) adopted under the framework of the Convention. The Convention encourages the signature of multilateral cooperation agreements under its umbrella.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Council Directive 86/609/EEC of 24 November 1986 on the approximation of laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States regarding the protection of animals used for experimental and other scientific purposes

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The aim of this Directive is to ensure that where animals are used for experimental or other scientific purposes, the provisions for the animal's protection laid down by law or regulation or administrative provisions in the Member States, are approximated. At regular intervals Member States shall inform the Commission of the measures taken in this area and provide a suitable summary of the statistical information on the use of animals in experiments.

column.value: A Community-wide procedure for the exchange of information and data on ambient air quality in the European Community is established by the Council Decision 97/101/EC. column.name: TITLE
column.value: Montreal Protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer

column.name: LEGAL_NAME
column.value: Montreal Protocol on Substances depleting the Ozone Layer

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The Montreal Protocol was signed on September 16, 1987, in Montreal, Canada. The focus of the Montreal Protocol is the control of production and consumption of bulk Ozone Depleting Substances. (Consumption is defined as production + imports - exports). The protocol was adjusted and/or amended in 1990, 1992, 1995, 1997 and in Beijing in 1999.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: The link to the instrument above is a link to the consolidated text of the protocol i.e. the text including adjustments and amendments. The CELEX number 21988A1031(02) refers to the original protocol text in CELEX (http://eur-lex.europa.eu/Result.do?RechType=RECH_celex&lang=en&code=21988A1031(02)).

column.name: LEGAL_NAME
column.value: Conventions establishing the International Maritime Organisation

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The International Maritime Organization is the United Nations' specialized agency responsible for improving maritime safety and preventing pollution from ships. Around 40 conventions and protocols have been adopted by the Organization and most of them have been amended on several occasions to ensure that they are kept up to date with changes taking place in world shipping.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: There are reporting obligations here but they are not environmental obligations, mostly technical and not requiring monitoring or assessment data on state of the environment or pressures on the environment, so they have not been included here. They may need to be considered later if information is needed for Reponses to environmental problems in the DPSIR scheme. They are not legal except for those incorporated into international laws

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Joint Declaration on the Protection of the Wadden Sea

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: Since 1978, The Netherlands, Denmark and Germany have been working together on the protection and conservation of the Wadden Sea covering management, monitoring and research, as well as political matters. In 1982, a Joint Declaration on the Protection of the Wadden Sea was agreed upon in which the countries declare their intention to coordinate their activities and measures for the protection of the Wadden Sea. In 1997, a Trilateral Wadden Sea Plan was adopted.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EC) No 401/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 April 2009 on the European Environment Agency and the European Environment Information and Observation Network

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The regulation describes the aims and objectives of the European Environment Agency (EEA) and the European Environment Information and Observation Network (EIONET). This enables them to provide information in support of the formulation of EU environmental policy. The EEA is an EU agency whose objective is to protect and improve the environment and support sustainable development. It does this by providing objective, reliable and comparable information.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: Reporting obligations are listed under the EEA Annual Work Programme, http://rod.eionet.europa.eu/instruments/499

column.value: The International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973, as modified by the Protocol of 1978 relating thereto

column.name: LEGAL_NAME
column.value: The International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973, as modified by the Protocol of 1978 relating thereto (MARPOL 73/78).

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The MARPOL Convention is the main international convention covering prevention of pollution of the marine environment by ships from operational or accidental causes. It is a combination of two treaties adopted in 1973 and 1978 respectively and updated by amendments through the years.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2001/80/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 October 2001 on the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air from large combustion plants

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value:
This Directive shall apply to combustion plants, the rated thermal input of which is equal to or greater than 50 MW, irrespective of the type of fuel used (solid, liquid or gaseous). Its purpose is to limit the emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust emitted from these plants.
New reporting obligations concerning the emission inventories apply since 2004 as set out in Annex VIII(B) of the Directive.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals

column.name: SECRETARIAT
column.value: Secretariat for the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (UNEP/CMS Secretariat) (in Bonn, Germany)

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The Bonn Convention aims to conserve terrestrial, marine and avian migratory species throughout their range. Parties to the Convention work together to conserve migratory species and their habitats by providing strict protection for the endangered migratory species listed in Appendix I of the Convention, by concluding multilateral Agreements for the conservation and management of migratory species listed in Appendix II, and by undertaking co-operative research activities.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Council Directive 91/271/EEC of 21 May 1991 concerning urban waste water treatment as amended by Commission Directive 98/15/EC and Regulations 1882/2003/EC and 1137/2008/EC

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Council Directive 92/72/EEC of 21 September 1992 on air pollution by ozone

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The purpose of this directive is to establish a harmonized procedure - for monitoring,-for exchanging information, - for informing and warning the population, with regard to air pollution by ozone.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: Repealed by Directive 2002/3/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 12 February 2002 relating to ozone in ambient air, with effect from 9 September 2003.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Council Directive 96/82/EC of 9 December 1996 on the control of major-accident hazards involving dangerous substances

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The aim of the Seveso II Directive is two-fold. Firstly, the Directive aims at the prevention of major accident hazards involving dangerous substances. Secondly, as accidents do continue to occur, the Directive aims at the limitation of the consequences of such accidents not only for man (safety and health aspects) but also for the environment (environmental aspects).

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Council Regulation (EC) No 338/97 of 9 December 1996 on the protection of species of wild fauna and flora by regulating trade therein

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The aim of the EU Trade Regulation is to protect wild animals and plants currently or likely to become threatened by international trade, by regulating the trade in these species. It enforces the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) within the EU and provides additional measures for the conservation of species in trade.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: Amended by Commission Regulation (EC) No 1497/2003 of 18 August 2003 amending Council Regulation (EC) No 338/97 on the protection of species of wild fauna and flora by regulating trade therein.

Working Group on Environmental Monitoring
The Working Group on Environmental Monitoring serves as an instrument for UNECE Member States to provide recommendations, to propose action plans, and to strengthen international initiatives within the region in the area of environmental monitoring and related areas of common interest for cooperation.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 98/70/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 October 1998 relating to the quality of petrol and diesel fuels as amended by Directive 2009/30/EC

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: By 31 August each year the Member States must submit information according to Article 8(1) and 7a of Directive 98/70/EC (as amended). Article 8 (1) requires a summary of fuel quality monitoring data collected during the period January to December of the previous calendar year. Article 7a imposes requirements on fuel suppliers to reduce the greenhouse gas intensity of energy supplied for road transport.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2005/33/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 July 2005 amending Directive 1999/32/EC (Council Directive 1999/32/EC of 26 April 1999 relating to a reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels and amending Directive 93/12/EEC)

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: On the basis of the results of the sampling and analysis carried out in accordance with Article 6, Member States shall by 30 June of each year supply the Commission with a short report on the sulphur content of the liquid fuels falling within the scope of this Directive and used within their territory during the preceding calendar year.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: Implicitly repealed by Directive (EU) 2016/802 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 May 2016 relating to a reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels, with effect from 2016-06-10.

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The purpose of this Directive is to ensure that information relating to the fuel economy and CO2 emissions of new passenger cars offered for sale or lease in the Community is made available to consumers in order to enable consumers to make an informed choice.

column.value: Regulation (EC) No 1005/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 September 2009 on substances that deplete the ozone layer

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This regulation lays down rules on the production, import, export, placing on the market, use, recovery, recycling, reclamation and destruction of substances that deplete the ozone layer, on the reporting of information related to those substances and on the import, export, placing on the market and use of products and equipment containing or relying on those substances.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: The ODS Regulation (EC) No 1005/2009, is a recast of Regulation (EC) No 2037/2000 and its amendments. The following amendments apply to the ODS Regulation: - Commission Decision on the use of controlled substances as process agents under Article 8(4) - Regulation on substances that deplete the ozone layer, with regard to the critical uses of halons amending the ODS Regulation

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 12 March 2001 on the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms and repealing Council Directive 90/220/EEC

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The objective of this Directive is to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States of the European Union and to protect human health and the environment when: 1) carrying out the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any other purposes than placing on the market within the Community; and 2) placing on the market genetically modified organisms as or in products within the Community.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Council Directive 92/43/EEC of 21 May 1992 on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The Directive requires Member States to designate sites based on species and habitats in the Directive's annexes. It thereby establishes the Natura 2000 network of protected sites, which also includes the sites designated according to the Birds Directive. Furthermore, the Directive also deals with the protection of species (animals and plants) over the whole territory of a Member State.

column.value: The aim of the joint OECD/Eurostat questionnaire is to progressively improve the quality of data, to arrive at harmonised statistics at the international level and to improve data relevance for international work.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: The official languages of the Alpine Convention are French, German, Italian and Slovene. The Alpine Convention itself has been ratified by the European Union and consequently has been translated into the EU languages, including English. However, to date, none of the Protocols have been ratified by the EU, and therefore they have not been translated into English.

The objective of Directive 98/81/EC is to lay down common measures for the contained use of genetically modified micro-organisms for the purposes of protecting human health and the environment.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value:
The first International Tropical Timber Agreement was negotiated in 1983 with a limited life span under the auspices of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD). The current ITTA was negotiated in 1994 and is the successor agreement to the ITTA (1983). The ITTA is being renegotiated during 2005/2006 under the auspices of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD).

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The objective of the SPAW Protocol is to protect rare and fragile ecosystems and habitats, thereby protecting the endangered and threatened species residing therein. The Caribbean Regional Co-ordinating Unit pursues this objective by assisting with the establishment and proper management of protected areas, by promoting sustainable management (and use) of species to prevent their endangerment and by providing assistance to the governments of the region in conserving their coastal ecosystems.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: UNECE Convention on the Transboundary Effects of Industrial Accidents

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The Convention aims at protecting human beings and the environment against industrial accidents by preventing such accidents as far as possible, by reducing their frequency and severity and by mitigating their effects. To respond effectively and in a coordinated way to an industrial accident, Parties must be informed as soon as possible, since time is of the essence. The Parties must set up a special Industrial Accident Notification System.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: The reporting under the Industrial Accident Notification System is not included in ROD. Reporting guidelines can be found at: http://www.unece.org/env/teia/system.htm

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The aim of the Directive is to harmonize national measures on classification, packaging and labelling of dangerous substances. The 7th amendment of 1992, in particular required that the principles of risk assessment for 'new' substances be laid down. It further introduced the 'sole representative' in the notification system, and added the Safety Data Sheet as a hazard communication facility for the professional user.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Council Directive 82/883/EEC of 3 December 1982 on procedures for the surveillance and monitoring of environments concerned by waste from the titanium dioxide industry

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This Directive lays down, pursuant to Article 7(3) of Directive 78/176/EEC, the procedures for the surveillance and monitoring of the effects on the environment, having regard to its physical, chemical, biological and ecological aspects, of the discharge, dumping, storage on, tipping on or injection into the ground of waste from the titanium dioxide industry.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value:
The media concerned are the water, the land surface and underground strata and the air in or into which waste from the titanium dioxide industry is discharged, dumped, stored, tipped or injected.
=======

column.value: Council Directive 91/414/EEC of 15 July 1991 concerning the placing of plant protection products on the market

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This directive concerns the authorization, placing on the market, use, and control within the Community of plant protection products on commercial form and the placing on the market and control within the Community of active substances intended for a use specified in art. 2.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Commission Regulation (EC) No 1488/94 of 28 June 1994 laying down the principles for the assessment of risks to man and the environment of existing substances in accordance with Council Regulation (EEC) No 793/93

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This Regulation lays down general principles for the assessment of the risks posed by existing substances to man and the environment as required by Article 10 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 793/93.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: The definitions contained in Article 2 of Regulation (EEC) No 793/93 are applicable to this Regulation.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EC) No 850/2004 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 29 April 2004 on persistent organic pollutants and amending Directive 79/117/EEC

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EC) No 166/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 18 January 2006 concerning the establishment of a European Pollutant Release and Transfer Register and amending Council Directives 91/689/EEC and 96/61/EC (Text with EEA relevance)

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This Regulation establishes an integrated pollutant release and transfer register at EU level in the form of a publicly accessible electronic database and lays down rules for its functioning, in order to implement the UNECE Protocol on Pollutant Release and Transfer Registers and facilitate public participation in environmental decision-making, as well as contributing to the prevention and reduction of pollution of the environment.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: The Protocol builds on the same principles as EPER, but goes beyond, by including reporting on more pollutants, more activities, releases to land, releases from diffuse sources and off-site transfers. An adequate harmonisation of the data collection and transfer system is therefore needed to ensure the quality and comparability of data. In accordance with the Protocol the European PRTR should be designed for maximum ease of public access through the Internet.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Council Regulation (EEC) No 793/93 of 23 March 1993 on the evaluation and control of the risks of existing substances

column.name: ABSTRACT
COMMENT
column.value: Art. 10 describes the risk evaluation of the substances on the priority lists at the level of the Member State designated as rapporteur

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The main aim of the Protocol is to protect human health and well being by better water management, including the protection of water ecosystems, and by preventing, controlling and reducing water-related diseases.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2007/60/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 October 2007 on the assessment and management of flood risks

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value:
The purpose of this Directive is to establish a framework for the assessment and management of flood risks, aiming at the reduction of the adverse consequences for human health, the environment, cultural heritage and economic activity associated with floods in the Community.
The Directive covers all types of floods, including fluvial, pluvial, coastal and groundwater floods as well as floods from artificial water-bearing infrastructure and may exclude floods from sewerage systems.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2008/56/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 June 2008 establishing a framework for community action in the field of marine environmental policy

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: Coastal waters, including their seabed and subsoil, are an integral part of the marine environment, and as such should also be covered by this Directive, in so far as particular aspects of the environmental status of the marine environment are not already addressed through Directive 2000/60/EC or other Community legislation. This Directive is consistent with the Water Framework Directive. See for its reporting obligations http://rod.eionet.europa.eu/show.jsv?id=516&mode=S

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2007/2/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 March 2007 establishing an Infrastructure for Spatial Information in the European Community (INSPIRE)

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2008/105/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 December 2008 on environmental quality standards in the field of water policy, amending and subsequently repealing Council Directives 82/176/EEC, 83/513/EEC, 84/156/EEC, 84/491/EEC, 86/280/EEC and amending Directive 2000/60/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This Directive lays down environmental quality standards (EQS) for priority substances and certain other pollutants as provided for in Article 16 of the Water Framework Directive 2000/60/EC (WFD), with the aim of achieving good surface water chemical status and in accordance with the provisions and objectives of Article 4 of that Directive.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value:
Environmental Quality Standards Directive (EQSD) is Daughter Directive of the Water Framework Directive 2000/60/EC.
The deadline for transposition of this Directive in Member States is 13/07/2010. However, till then it is recommended that the reporting obligations to be done in accordance with the general requirements settled in Article 12(2) of the EQSD.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EC) No 443/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 April 2009 setting emission performance standards for new passenger cars as part of the Community's integrated approach to reduce CO2 emissions from light-duty vehicles

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This Regulation builds on a well-established process of measuring and monitoring the CO2 emissions of vehicles registered in the Community in accordance with Decision No 1753/2000/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 June 2000 establishing a scheme to monitor the average specific emissions of CO2 from new passenger cars.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2003/30/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 8 May 2003 on the promotion of the use of biofuels or other renewable fuels for transport

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: Article 1 This Directive aims at promoting the use of biofuels or other renewable fuels to replace diesel or petrol for transport purposes in each Member State, with a view to contributing to objectives such as meeting climate change commitments, environmentally friendly security of supply and promoting renewable energy sources.

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: Repealed by Directive 2009/28/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 April 2009 on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources and amending and subsequently repealing Directives 2001/77/EC and 2003/30/EC, with effect from 1 January 2012.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2004/42/CE of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 April 2004 on the limitation of emissions of volatile organic compounds due to the use of organic solvents in certain paints and varnishes and vehicle refinishing products and amending Directive 1999/13/EC

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value:
The purpose of this Directive is to limit the total content of VOCs in certain paints and varnishes and vehicle refinishing products in order to prevent or reduce air pollution resulting from the contribution of VOCs to the formation of tropospheric ozone. Art 1(1)
More information at http://ec.europa.eu/environment/air/pollutants/paints_directive.htm

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EU) No 525/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 May 2013 on a mechanism for monitoring and reporting greenhouse gas emissions and for reporting other information at national and Union level relevant to climate change and repealing Decision No 280/2004/EC

column.name: COMMENT
column.value: The Commission adopted implementing acts to set out the structure, format and submission process of information required under the MMR.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: DIRECTIVE 2009/41/EC OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 6 May 2009 on the contained use of genetically modified micro-organisms

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This Directive lays down common measures for the contained use of genetically modified micro-organisms with a view to protecting human health and the environment.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EU) No 517/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 April 2014 on fluorinated greenhouse gases and repealing Regulation (EC) No 842/2006

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The objective of this Regulation is to protect the environment by reducing emissions of fluorinated greenhouse gases.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2009/147/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 November 2009 on the conservation of wild birds

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive (EU) 2015/2193 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2015 on the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air from medium combustion plants

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This Directive lays down rules to control emissions of sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx) and dust into the air from medium combustion plants, and thereby reduce emissions to air and the potential risks to human health and the environment from such emissions. This Directive also lays down rules to monitor emissions of carbon monoxide (CO).

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EU) No 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 October 2014 on the prevention and management of the introduction and spread of invasive alien species

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The European Union has adopted a law which seeks to prevent, minimise and mitigate the adverse effects of invasive alien species (IASs) on its biodiversity and ecosystems, as well as on human health and the economy.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2012/18/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 4 July 2012 on the control of major-accident hazards involving dangerous substances, amending and subsequently repealing Council Directive 96/82/EC

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This Directive lays down rules for the prevention of major accidents which involve dangerous substances, and the limitation of their consequences for human health and the environment, with a view to ensuring a high level of protection throughout the Union in a consistent and effective manner.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EC) No 1221/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009 on the voluntary participation by organisations in a Community eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS), repealing Regulation (EC) No 761/2001 and Commission Decisions 2001/681/EC and 2006/193/EC

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The European Union eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS) aims to encourage companies and other organisations to continually improve their environmental performance. It is open to any organisation inside or outside the EU, spans all economic and service sectors and is applicable worldwide.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive (EU) 2016/802 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 May 2016 relating to a reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The purpose of this Directive is to reduce the emissions of sulphur dioxide resulting from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels and thereby to reduce the harmful effects of such emissions on man and the environment. The Directive is a codification of Council Directive 1999/32/EC, which has been substantially amended several times.

column.name: ALIAS
column.value: Sulphur Content of Certain Liquid Fuels Directive

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EU) No 995/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 October 2010 laying down the obligations of operators who place timber and timber products on the market

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: Illegal logging is a global problem with significant negative economic, environmental and social impact. To combat this threat, the European Union has adopted this law. It prohibits illegally harvested timber from being placed on the EU market, and sets out preconditions for the marketing of timber and timber products in the EU.

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Directive 2009/31/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 April 2009 on the geological storage of carbon dioxide and amending Council Directive 85/337/EEC, European Parliament and Council Directives 2000/60/EC, 2001/80/EC, 2004/35/EC, 2006/12/EC, 2008/1/EC and Regulation (EC) No 1013/2006

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This Regulation establishes a common framework for the systematic production of Community statistics on the placing on the market and use of those pesticides which are plant protection products, as defined in Article 2(a)(i).

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EU) No 691/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 July 2011 on European environmental economic accounts

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: This Regulation establishes a common framework for the collection, compilation, transmission and evaluation of European environmental economic accounts, for the purpose of setting up environmental economic accounts as satellite accounts to ESA 95, by providing methodology, common standards, definitions, classifications and accounting rules intended to be used for compiling environmental economic accounts.

column.name: ALIAS
column.value: Regulation on European environmental economic accounts

column.value: European Union, Text with EEA relevance

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 September 2009 on trade in seal products

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: Seals are hunted inside and outside the EU for a variety of purposes. They are used to obtain meat, oil, blubber, organs and fur skins, and for articles as diverse as Omega-3 capsules and clothing. This Regulation establishes harmonised rules concerning the placing on the market of seal products.

column.name: ALIAS
column.value: Regulation on trade in seal products

column.name: GEOGRAPHIC_SCOPE
column.value: European Union, Text with EEA relevance

column.name: TITLE
column.value: Regulation (EU) No 1257/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 November 2013 on ship recycling and amending Regulation (EC) No 1013/2006 and Directive 2009/16/EC

column.name: ABSTRACT
column.value: The purpose of this Regulation is to prevent, reduce, minimise and, to the extent practicable, eliminate accidents, injuries and other adverse effects on human health and the environment caused by ship recycling. The purpose of this Regulation is to enhance safety, the protection of human health and of the Union marine environment throughout a ships life-cycle, in particular to ensure that hazardous waste from such ship recycling is subject to environmentally sound management.
